text: Titus Statilius Maximus was a Roman senator of the 2nd century AD. He was consul in the year 144 as the colleague of Lucius Hedius Rufus Lollianus Avitus.Werner Eck, "Die Fasti consulares der Regungszeit des Antoninus Pius, eine Bestandsaufnahme seit Géza Alföldys Konsulat und Senatorenstand" in Studia epigraphica in memoriam Géza Alföldy, hg. W. Eck, B. Feher, and P. Kovács (Bonn, 2013), p. 74 He is known entirely from inscriptions. Maximus was descended from a wealthy Syrian family; Géza Alföldy has identified two of his relatives active in that province, one the patron of Heliopolis (modern Baalbek), the other a prominent citizen of Beirut.Alföldy, Konsulat und Senatorenstand unter der Antoninen (Bonn: Rudolf Habelt Verlag, 1977), p. 319 He was the son of Titus Statilius Maximus Severus Hadrianus, consul in 115.Alföldy, Konsulat und Senatorenstand, p. 323 It is possible Maximus was the father of Titus Statilius Severus, consul in 171.Alföldy, Konsulat und Senatorenstand, p. 325 We are certain of two of the offices Maximus held as a senator, both after he stepped down from the consulate. Maximus is attested as curator aedium sacrarum in the year 146.Alföldy, Konsulat und Senatorenstand, p. 323 For the period 157/158, he was proconsular governor of Asia.Der Neue Pauly, Stuttgardiae 1999, T. 11, c. 923 ==References== Category:2nd-century Romans Category:Imperial Roman consuls Category:Roman governors of Asia Maximus
title: Titus Statilius Maximus
